articles.title: High-achieving adults rarely began as child prodigies
articles.summary: It's easy to assume that the most talented adults among us were once gifted children, but it turns out that talent during childhood is no guide to later success
articles.content:
It's easy to assume that the most talented adults among us were once gifted children, but it turns out that talent during childhood is no guide to later success

Award-winning athletes may have been late bloomers when it came to developing their skills Michael Steele/Getty Images

International chess masters, Olympic gold medallists and Nobel prize-winning scientists were rarely child prodigies, a review reveals. Likewise, early childhood successes and intense training programmes have rarely led to top achievement at a global level in the adult world.

The analysis – based on 19 studies involving nearly 35,000 high-performing people – shows that the vast majority of adults who lead worldwide rankings in their field of expertise grew up participating in a broad range of activities, only gradually developing their most proficient skill.

Advertisement

The findings contradict popular beliefs that achieving top international performance levels requires intensive, highly focused training during childhood, says Arne Güllich at RPTU Kaiserslautern in Germany. “If we understand that most world-class performers were not that remarkable or exceptional in their early years, this implies that early exceptional performance is not a prerequisite for long-term, world-class performance.”

Much research has strongly linked the intensity of a child’s training programme in specific activities – like music and athletics – to competitive performance in those activities as teenagers or young adults. But studies in older world-class athletes have shown trends to the contrary. For example, 82 per cent of international-level junior athletes don’t become international-level adult, or senior, athletes, and 72 per cent of international-level seniors didn’t previously achieve the junior international level.

The backgrounds of famous international experts also suggest the link between childhood and adult success isn’t as strong as it might appear. For instance, although composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, golfer Tiger Woods, chess player Gukesh Dommaraju and mathematician Terence Tao were all child prodigies, composer Ludwig van Beethoven, basketball player Michael Jordan, chess player Viswanathan Anand and scientist Charles Darwin were not.

The studies that Güllich and his colleagues reviewed included analyses of the life histories of Olympic athletes, Nobel laureates in the sciences, world top-10 chess players and the most renowned classical music composers, as well as international leaders in other fields.

Across various specialisms, early high achievers and later world-class performers were largely different people. Indeed, only about 10 per cent of those who excelled as adults were top performers in their youth, and only about 10 per cent of top youth performers went on to excel as adults.

The team also compared their results with data from 66 studies on the training histories of young and “sub-elite” performers – those reaching high local levels or junior championships but not necessarily the best in the world as seniors. They noted that traits that distinguish high-achieving youths, like early specialisation, rapid progress and abundant discipline-specific practice are largely absent – or even reversed – among adult world-class performers.

That might be because children who gain a broader early experience in various activities end up developing more flexible learning skills, and finding the activities that fit them the best. “In essence, they find an optimal discipline match and they enhance their learning capital for future long-term learning,” says Güllich.

Plus, having a less intense training schedule during childhood and adolescence could potentially help prevent burnout or injuries that can compromise long-term careers. “There’s this increased risk of getting stuck in a discipline you cease to enjoy and have no alternative to change,” says Güllich.

The review addresses a long-standing research gap by clearly separating early success from long-term elite performance, says David Feldon at Utah State University. He says there is still a tendency to encourage children to focus hard on learning and practising a particular skill. “It certainly does develop expertise and leads to quick gains,” he says. “But I don’t know that it’s ultimately productive for people over their lifespans.”

For Feldon, who is also a children’s wrestling coach, the review has important implications for those who work with children to help them develop skills. “It’s not just helping foster very high levels of expertise, but doing so in a way that is healthy and productive, and which leads to the betterment of people in a broader sense, not just in a very narrow attainment of outcome.”

Programmes designed to identify and fast-track early stars might thus miss many future top performers, while favouring pathways that optimise short-term success rather than long-term excellence, Güllich adds. “Those elite training programmes, giftedness programmes, scholarship programmes, and so on, that typically focus on very young ages and on just one discipline? Well, as we now know from recent evidence, it’ll be more promising to encourage young people to do at least one, maybe two other disciplines over multiple years.”
articles.reasoning: The article presents a well-supported, research-based insight that challenges common assumptions about early childhood talent and long-term success. It highlights that broad early experiences and less intense childhood specialization can lead to healthier, more sustainable achievement in adulthood across diverse fields. This has broad societal implications for education, youth development, and talent nurturing programs, encouraging more balanced approaches that benefit many children and future adults.
articles.personality_title: Most top adults were not child prodigies, new research shows
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many people believe that adults who become very successful in fields like sports, music, or science were child prodigies, showing special talent from a young age. This idea has led to early intense training programs aimed at developing young stars.

**What happened** – A review of 19 studies involving nearly 35,000 high-achieving individuals found that most world-class adults were not exceptional children. Instead, they tried many activities growing up and only developed their main skill later. Only about 10% of top adults were top performers as children, and 90% of child stars did not become top adults.

**Impact** – This research challenges the common belief that early talent and focused training guarantee adult success. It shows that broad experiences and less intense early training can help people find the right path and avoid burnout or injuries. For example, famous adults like Michael Jordan and Charles Darwin were not child prodigies, yet they reached the top of their fields.

**What's next step** – Experts suggest changing youth training programs to encourage children to explore multiple activities over several years instead of pushing early specialization. This approach could help more children develop skills in a healthy way and increase the chances of long-term success.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Most world-class adults did not start as child prodigies but grew their talents gradually through varied experiences and balanced training.
articles.personality_title_fr: La plupart des adultes de haut niveau n’étaient pas des enfants prodiges, selon une nouvelle étude
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Beaucoup pensent que les adultes très talentueux dans des domaines comme le sport, la musique ou la science étaient des enfants prodiges, montrant un talent spécial dès le plus jeune âge. Cette idée a conduit à des programmes d’entraînement intensifs très tôt.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une revue de 19 études portant sur près de 35 000 personnes très performantes montre que la plupart des adultes de classe mondiale n’étaient pas exceptionnels enfants. Ils ont plutôt essayé plusieurs activités en grandissant et n’ont développé leur compétence principale que plus tard. Environ 10 % des adultes au sommet étaient aussi au sommet enfants, et 90 % des enfants prodiges ne sont pas devenus des adultes au sommet.

**Impact** – Cette recherche remet en question la croyance selon laquelle un talent précoce et un entraînement ciblé garantissent le succès adulte. Elle montre que des expériences variées et un entraînement moins intense tôt aident à trouver la bonne voie et évitent l’épuisement ou les blessures. Par exemple, des adultes célèbres comme Michael Jordan ou Charles Darwin n’étaient pas des enfants prodiges, mais ont atteint le sommet dans leurs domaines.

**Prochaine étape** – Les experts suggèrent de modifier les programmes pour encourager les enfants à explorer plusieurs activités sur plusieurs années plutôt que de se spécialiser très tôt. Cela pourrait aider plus d’enfants à développer leurs compétences de façon saine et augmenter leurs chances de succès à long terme.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La plupart des adultes de classe mondiale ont développé leur talent progressivement grâce à des expériences variées et un entraînement équilibré, sans être des enfants prodiges.
articles.personality_title_es: La mayoría de los adultos exitosos no fueron niños prodigios, revela investigación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchas personas creen que los adultos muy exitosos en deportes, música o ciencia fueron niños prodigios, mostrando talento especial desde pequeños. Esta idea ha llevado a programas de entrenamiento intenso desde la infancia.

**Qué pasó** – Un análisis de 19 estudios con casi 35,000 personas muy destacadas encontró que la mayoría de los adultos de clase mundial no fueron niños excepcionales. Más bien, probaron muchas actividades mientras crecían y desarrollaron su habilidad principal más tarde. Sólo cerca del 10 % de los adultos exitosos fueron también destacados en la niñez, y el 90 % de los niños prodigios no llegaron a ser adultos exitosos.

**Impacto** – Esta investigación desafía la creencia común de que el talento temprano y el entrenamiento enfocado aseguran el éxito adulto. Muestra que tener experiencias variadas y un entrenamiento menos intenso en la infancia ayuda a encontrar el camino correcto y evita agotamiento o lesiones. Por ejemplo, adultos famosos como Michael Jordan y Charles Darwin no fueron niños prodigios, pero alcanzaron la cima en sus campos.

**Próximo paso** – Los expertos sugieren cambiar los programas de entrenamiento infantil para animar a los niños a explorar varias actividades durante varios años en lugar de especializarse temprano. Esto podría ayudar a más niños a desarrollar habilidades de manera saludable y aumentar sus posibilidades de éxito a largo plazo.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La mayoría de los adultos de clase mundial desarrollaron su talento poco a poco mediante experiencias variadas y entrenamiento equilibrado, sin ser niños prodigios.

articles.title: Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov presented Bulgarian euro coins to the European leaders
articles.summary: He assured that Bulgaria is ready to be an active and responsible partner within the EU monetary union
articles.content:
He assured that Bulgaria is ready to be an active and responsible partner within the EU monetary union

BRUSSELS – The Bulgarian caretaker Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov presented sets of the new Bulgarian euro coins to the Presidents of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen, of the European Parliament Roberta Metsola, of the European Council Antonio Costa, and to the leaders of the EU member states.

Bulgaria is ready to be an active and responsible partner within the EU’s monetary union, Zhelyazkov stated in a conversation with Ursula von der Leyen.

The adoption of the euro is the result of consistent efforts and reforms and will contribute to economic stability, greater confidence and new opportunities for Bulgarian citizens and businesses, said Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov.

He expressed gratitude for the consistent support of the European institutions in the process of Bulgaria’s accession to the euro area and acquainted the European leaders with the Bulgarian national symbols on the reverse of the coins, which reflect Bulgarian history, cultural identity and the country’s place in the European family.

The Bulgarian government has taken all necessary measures to ensure a smooth, transparent and successful transition to the euro, Prime Minister Zhelyazkov assured.

Before the President of the European Council, Zhelyazkov stated that with Bulgaria’s membership in the euro area from 1 January 2026, the European Union will be even stronger.

Bulgaria will officially adopt the euro and will become the 21st member of the euro area as of 1 January 2026 – 19 years after the country’s accession to the European Union. The Council of the EU voted unanimously on 8 July this year on the final decisions related to the adoption of the euro in Bulgaria. With this, the procedure was completed, after earlier the same day the European Parliament also approved by a large majority the report on the introduction of the single European currency by Bulgaria. (18.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports Bulgaria's upcoming adoption of the euro in 2026, marking a significant economic integration step within the EU. This event has broad positive implications for economic stability, confidence, and opportunities for Bulgarian citizens and businesses, reflecting a meaningful and substantive development with wide public impact.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria to join eurozone in 2026, strengthening its role in the EU
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria has been a member of the European Union since 2007 but has not yet used the euro as its currency. The country has worked for years to meet the rules needed to join the eurozone, the group of EU countries that use the euro.

**What happened** – On December 18, 2025, Bulgaria will officially adopt the euro, becoming the 21st member of the eurozone. Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov recently presented sets of the new Bulgarian euro coins to top European leaders, including the heads of the European Commission, Parliament, and Council. He explained that Bulgaria is ready to be an active and responsible partner in the EU’s monetary union.

**Impact** – Joining the eurozone means Bulgaria will use the euro instead of its own currency, which can help the country’s economy become more stable. It will be easier for Bulgarian businesses to trade with other eurozone countries, and people may feel more confident about the country’s financial future. The new coins also feature national symbols that show Bulgaria’s culture and history.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria will continue to prepare for the change to the euro, making sure everything goes smoothly and transparently. The government will support citizens and businesses as they get used to the new currency. This step also strengthens the European Union by adding a new member to the eurozone.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria will join the eurozone on January 1, 2026, marking a key step in its economic integration with Europe and offering new opportunities for its people and businesses.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bulgarie rejoindra la zone euro en 2026, renforçant son rôle dans l’UE
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie est membre de l’Union européenne depuis 2007, mais elle n’utilise pas encore l’euro comme monnaie. Le pays travaille depuis des années pour respecter les règles nécessaires afin de rejoindre la zone euro, le groupe de pays de l’UE qui utilisent l’euro.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 18 décembre 2025, la Bulgarie adoptera officiellement l’euro et deviendra le 21e membre de la zone euro. Le Premier ministre Rosen Zhelyazkov a récemment présenté des séries de nouvelles pièces en euros bulgares aux principaux dirigeants européens, dont les présidents de la Commission, du Parlement et du Conseil européens. Il a expliqué que la Bulgarie est prête à être un partenaire actif et responsable dans l’union monétaire de l’UE.

**Impact** – Rejoindre la zone euro signifie que la Bulgarie utilisera l’euro au lieu de sa propre monnaie, ce qui peut rendre son économie plus stable. Il sera plus facile pour les entreprises bulgares de commercer avec les autres pays de la zone euro, et les citoyens auront peut-être plus confiance dans l’avenir financier du pays. Les nouvelles pièces portent aussi des symboles nationaux qui reflètent la culture et l’histoire bulgares.

**Prochaine étape** – La Bulgarie continuera à se préparer au passage à l’euro, en veillant à ce que tout se passe de manière fluide et transparente. Le gouvernement soutiendra les citoyens et les entreprises pour qu’ils s’habituent à la nouvelle monnaie. Cette étape renforce aussi l’Union européenne en ajoutant un nouveau membre à la zone euro.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Bulgarie rejoindra la zone euro le 1er janvier 2026, marquant une étape clé de son intégration économique en Europe et offrant de nouvelles opportunités à ses habitants et entreprises.
articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria se unirá a la eurozona en 2026, fortaleciendo su papel en la UE
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria es miembro de la Unión Europea desde 2007, pero aún no usa el euro como moneda. El país ha trabajado durante años para cumplir las reglas necesarias para unirse a la eurozona, el grupo de países de la UE que usan el euro.

**Qué pasó** – El 18 de diciembre de 2025, Bulgaria adoptará oficialmente el euro y será el miembro número 21 de la eurozona. El primer ministro Rosen Zhelyazkov presentó recientemente juegos de las nuevas monedas de euro búlgaras a los principales líderes europeos, incluidos los presidentes de la Comisión Europea, el Parlamento y el Consejo. Dijo que Bulgaria está lista para ser un socio activo y responsable en la unión monetaria de la UE.

**Impacto** – Unirse a la eurozona significa que Bulgaria usará el euro en lugar de su propia moneda, lo que puede ayudar a que su economía sea más estable. Será más fácil para las empresas búlgaras comerciar con otros países de la eurozona, y las personas podrían tener más confianza en el futuro financiero del país. Las nuevas monedas también tienen símbolos nacionales que muestran la cultura e historia de Bulgaria.

**Próximo paso** – Bulgaria seguirá preparándose para el cambio al euro, asegurándose de que todo sea claro y sin problemas. El gobierno apoyará a los ciudadanos y empresas para que se acostumbren a la nueva moneda. Este paso también fortalece a la Unión Europea al añadir un nuevo miembro a la eurozona.

**Mensaje en una frase** – Bulgaria se unirá a la eurozona el 1 de enero de 2026, marcando un paso importante en su integración económica con Europa y ofreciendo nuevas oportunidades para su gente y negocios.
